## Introducing Latch Pods: Your Personal Computing Environment on the Cloud:

### What are Pods?
Pods are virtual computing environments that allow you to run analysis tools like Jupyter Labs and RStudio with resource requirements (CPUs, RAM) of your choice in <5 minutes.in the browser using data stored on Latch. With Pods, you can:
In this tutorial, we will learn:
After the tutorial, you will have your personal computing environment on Latch to start performing custom analyses.
### How to create and start using Pods
To create a new Pod, click the Apps dropdown and select “Create a new Pod”. You will be prompted to enter a Pod name and set up your personal computing environment.
### How to choose the right compute sizes
There are four Pod sizes that you can choose from: 4 cores and 8GiB of RAM, 8 cores and 32 GiB of RAM, 16 cores and 128 GiB of RAM, and 64 cores and 256GiB of RAM. Storage for a Pod ranges from 20 to 1000 gigabytes.  For most use cases, the first option should be sufficient.
If you want to use GitHub inside Pod or access Pod from the terminal of your personal computer, continue with the advanced steps below. Otherwise, click “Launch Pod”.
Note: Pods may take 5-15 minutes to start running.

## Developer Environment:

### RStudio & JupyterLab
Once a Pod has started, RStudio and JupyterLab will be available by default in your Pod. To access them, simply double click on the desired notebook, and copy paste the permanent endpoints from the sidebar.
Voila! Now, you will be able to open up Jupyter Labs or RStudio for downstream analyses.
### Remote Development
You can program with your favorite IDE, such as VSCode and Pycharm, and open them inside a running Pod to take full advantage of the Pod’s powerful computing environment.
### VSCode

inputs:
Writing the Dockerfile is straightforward, I think I've written all the essential stuff in it. Now I'm working on the third step. Two quick questions:
Would you recommend writing the script as a separate file in scripts dir and calling it via subprocess, or writing it as a function within wf/__init__.py?
How do I read LatchFile objects as strings, line by line?
outputs:
Hi there! Writing the script as a separate file in scripts dir and calling it via subprocess is recommended. To read LatchFile objects as strings, line by line you can use the following code:
```python
for line in latch_file.readlines():
    print(line)
``` 
I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

## Latch Data:

Here you can upload, store, and visualize your data. Data stored here can be analyzed by workflows on Latch and you can view the outputted results right here in Latch. To upload data you can either drag and drop it or click the upload button to select the data you want from your computer. Latch also allows you integrate with [BaseSpace](latch.wiki/basespace) and [mount an S3 Bucket](latch.wiki/mount-s3).

# Inputs:

### Manifest File
File describing all inputs. See [https://github.com/tsailabSJ/guideseq](https://github.com/tsailabSJ/guideseq) for instructions. For Latch, modify the manifest so that paths start at the input directory. For example, if you have a file in your input directory with path input_dir/data/undemux.r1.fastq.gz, write it as data/undemux.r1.fastq.gz.
### Input Directory
File containing all inputs with paths matching the manifest
### Only Identify and Filter
Skip the demultiplex, umitag, consolidate, align, and visualize steps. Only run identify and filter.
### Data is Demultiplexed
Skip the demultiplex step. Run umitag, consolidate, align, identify, filter, and visualize
### Output Directory
Will place the output directory here

# Frequently Asked Questions:

### What is your data policy?
All data is secure & private. Our formal policy will be posted here soon.
### What if I'm running into an error?
Please report it using the intercom button the bottom left. We will be responsive on intercom from 9am to 9pm PST every day of the week.
If it's really bad, feel free to tweet at us [@latchbio](https://twitter.com/LatchBio).
### How do I report a bug?
Or tweet at us [@latchbio](https://twitter.com/LatchBio).
### How do I request features or changes?
You can make a request through intercom, email any of the founders ([kyle@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:kyle@latch.bio) or [alfredo@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:fredo@latch.bio)) or send us a [tweet](https://twitter.com/LatchBio).
### What are you building next?
Our current goals for the next 3-4 weeks are to add many more pipelines relevant to CRISPR research. Here is a short list:
Please let us know if there are other pipelines you'd want us to add.
### Do you have plans to add "x" workflow?
Yes if you [request](latch.wikimailto:pipelinerequest@latch.bio) it :)

# What is the Latch SDK?:

It takes months to build infrastructure with the compute, storage, and user-friendly interface necessary to run bioinformatics pipelines at scale.
The Latch SDK is an open-source toolchain to define serverless bioinformatics workflows with plain python and deploy associated no-code interfaces using single command.
Bioinformatics workflows developed with the SDK automatically receive:
👉 Visit [docs.latch.bio](http://docs.latch.bio) to see the full developer documentation on how to upload your workflow to Latch using our Python SDK.

outputs: Hi there! Yes, you will need to start a new pod if you want to switch the cores midway. However, your installed libraries should be maintained between different pods as long as they are in the same project. If you have any further questions or concerns please don't hesitate to reach out again!

# CasTLE:

Workflows
Workflow Helpers
Upload Your Custom Workflow
Compute Environment
Pollock — Single-cell Visualizer
Visualizations
Integrations
Resources
© LATCH 2021 - v0.1
A statistical frame work called Cas9 high-Throughput maximum Likelihood Estimator (casTLE). For each gene, casTLE combines measurements from multiple targeting reagents to estimate a maximum effect size as well as a p-value associated with that effect.

## Latch Workflows:

Here is where all of your analysis will take place. Workflows contain two subsections: My Workflows and All Workflows. If this is the first time you are using Latch, you will likely have zero workflow in My Workflows. You can find your first workflow in the All Workflows tab. Here, you can choose to test run a few workflows by selecting Run Workflow. You can also choose to add workflows to My Workflow for quick reference to them in the future.
Please note that Verified workflows are built by Latch engineers, and hence will have higher quality and reliability. Other workflows are built by various community members, so make sure you try and test them yourself.
To test out a workflow this way click the Use Test Data button. This will fill out all of the necessary parameters with sample data, and then launch the workflow. If a workflow doesn’t have test data, you can easily download test data of your choice and upload them to Latch Data for use in the workflow.

## What should I do if I get stuck or encounter a problem when getting started?:

You've got several options here. If you've exhausted the docs or find them completely unhelpful (which if that's the case please do let us know), you are more than welcome to contact us with any problems, questions, feedback, bugs you might encounter. There is a contact us icon in the bottom left hand corner of the platform you can use to get in contact with us.
This will connect you with Alfredo our CEO, the one with intercom installed on his phone.
He will be responsive on intercom from 9am to 9pm PST every day of the week. You can also email us at [help@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:help@latch.bio) or tweet at us [@latchbio](https://twitter.com/LatchBio) and we will get back to you ASAP.

## Pipeline information:

[Nextflow](https://www.nextflow.io/docs/latest/tracing.html) provides excellent functionality for generating various reports relevant to the running and execution of the pipeline. This will allow you to troubleshoot errors with the running of the pipeline, and also provide you with other information such as launch commands, run times and resource usage.
pipeline_info/

# Frequently Asked Questions:

### What is your data policy?
All data is secure & private. Our formal policy will be posted here soon.
### What if I'm running into an error?
Please report it using the intercom button the bottom left. We will be responsive on intercom from 9am to 9pm PST every day of the week.
If it's really bad, feel free to tweet at us [@latchbio](https://twitter.com/LatchBio).
### How do I report a bug?
Or tweet at us [@latchbio](https://twitter.com/LatchBio).
### How do I request features or changes?
You can make a request through intercom, email any of the founders ([kyle@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:kyle@latch.bio) or [alfredo@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:fredo@latch.bio)) or send us a [tweet](https://twitter.com/LatchBio).
### What are you building next?
Our current goals for the next 3-4 weeks are to add many more pipelines relevant to CRISPR research. Here is a short list:
Please let us know if there are other pipelines you'd want us to add.
### Do you have plans to add "x" workflow?
Yes if you [request](latch.wikimailto:pipelinerequest@latch.bio) it :)

## Advanced:

### Integration with GitHub (Optional)
If you want to add a GitHub repository to Pod when Pod is created for the first time or commit to a GitHub repository in the future, you have to first set up your GitHub personal access token (PAT).
Personal access tokens (PATs) are an alternative to using passwords for authentication to GitHub when using the GitHub API or the command line.
How to set up your Personal Access Token
Loading your GitHub repository when starting a Pod
If you want to have a GitHub repository automatically added to your Pod, as you are starting a new Pod, you can:
### Set up SSH access (Optional)
You may want to set up SSH access for Pod if you want to access Pod from your local terminal or open your favorite IDE, such as Visual Studio Code, inside a Pod.
$ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
If you receive an error message saying that id_rsa.pub doesn’t exist, it means that your computer doesn’t have a public SSH key.
Generate one using ssh-keygen:$ ssh-keygen
Note: Latch only authorizes access to users whose public SSH keys are added here. If you have multiple developers on the team who want to access the same Pod, it is recommended that you add their keys here. Latch supports up to 50 keys for each Pod.

## Introducing Latch Pods: Your Personal Computing Environment on the Cloud:

### What are Pods?
Pods are virtual computing environments that allow you to run analysis tools like Jupyter Labs and RStudio with resource requirements (CPUs, RAM) of your choice in <5 minutes.in the browser using data stored on Latch. With Pods, you can:
In this tutorial, we will learn:
After the tutorial, you will have your personal computing environment on Latch to start performing custom analyses.
### How to create and start using Pods
To create a new Pod, click the Apps dropdown and select “Create a new Pod”. You will be prompted to enter a Pod name and set up your personal computing environment.
### How to choose the right compute sizes
There are four Pod sizes that you can choose from: 4 cores and 8GiB of RAM, 8 cores and 32 GiB of RAM, 16 cores and 128 GiB of RAM, and 64 cores and 256GiB of RAM. Storage for a Pod ranges from 20 to 1000 gigabytes.  For most use cases, the first option should be sufficient.
If you want to use GitHub inside Pod or access Pod from the terminal of your personal computer, continue with the advanced steps below. Otherwise, click “Launch Pod”.
Note: Pods may take 5-15 minutes to start running.

## Developer Environment:

### RStudio & JupyterLab
Once a Pod has started, RStudio and JupyterLab will be available by default in your Pod. To access them, simply double click on the desired notebook, and copy paste the permanent endpoints from the sidebar.
Voila! Now, you will be able to open up Jupyter Labs or RStudio for downstream analyses.
### Remote Development
You can program with your favorite IDE, such as VSCode and Pycharm, and open them inside a running Pod to take full advantage of the Pod’s powerful computing environment.
### VSCode

## Introducing Latch Pods: Your Personal Computing Environment on the Cloud:

### What are Pods?
Pods are virtual computing environments that allow you to run analysis tools like Jupyter Labs and RStudio with resource requirements (CPUs, RAM) of your choice in <5 minutes.in the browser using data stored on Latch. With Pods, you can:
In this tutorial, we will learn:
After the tutorial, you will have your personal computing environment on Latch to start performing custom analyses.
### How to create and start using Pods
To create a new Pod, click the Apps dropdown and select “Create a new Pod”. You will be prompted to enter a Pod name and set up your personal computing environment.
### How to choose the right compute sizes
There are four Pod sizes that you can choose from: 4 cores and 8GiB of RAM, 8 cores and 32 GiB of RAM, 16 cores and 128 GiB of RAM, and 64 cores and 256GiB of RAM. Storage for a Pod ranges from 20 to 1000 gigabytes.  For most use cases, the first option should be sufficient.
If you want to use GitHub inside Pod or access Pod from the terminal of your personal computer, continue with the advanced steps below. Otherwise, click “Launch Pod”.
Note: Pods may take 5-15 minutes to start running.

## Advanced:

### Integration with GitHub (Optional)
If you want to add a GitHub repository to Pod when Pod is created for the first time or commit to a GitHub repository in the future, you have to first set up your GitHub personal access token (PAT).
Personal access tokens (PATs) are an alternative to using passwords for authentication to GitHub when using the GitHub API or the command line.
How to set up your Personal Access Token
Loading your GitHub repository when starting a Pod
If you want to have a GitHub repository automatically added to your Pod, as you are starting a new Pod, you can:
### Set up SSH access (Optional)
You may want to set up SSH access for Pod if you want to access Pod from your local terminal or open your favorite IDE, such as Visual Studio Code, inside a Pod.
$ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
If you receive an error message saying that id_rsa.pub doesn’t exist, it means that your computer doesn’t have a public SSH key.
Generate one using ssh-keygen:$ ssh-keygen
Note: Latch only authorizes access to users whose public SSH keys are added here. If you have multiple developers on the team who want to access the same Pod, it is recommended that you add their keys here. Latch supports up to 50 keys for each Pod.

## Developer Environment:

### RStudio & JupyterLab
Once a Pod has started, RStudio and JupyterLab will be available by default in your Pod. To access them, simply double click on the desired notebook, and copy paste the permanent endpoints from the sidebar.
Voila! Now, you will be able to open up Jupyter Labs or RStudio for downstream analyses.
### Remote Development
You can program with your favorite IDE, such as VSCode and Pycharm, and open them inside a running Pod to take full advantage of the Pod’s powerful computing environment.
### VSCode

## What should I do if I get stuck or encounter a problem when getting started?:

You've got several options here. If you've exhausted the docs or find them completely unhelpful (which if that's the case please do let us know), you are more than welcome to contact us with any problems, questions, feedback, bugs you might encounter. There is a contact us icon in the bottom left hand corner of the platform you can use to get in contact with us.
This will connect you with Alfredo our CEO, the one with intercom installed on his phone.
He will be responsive on intercom from 9am to 9pm PST every day of the week. You can also email us at [help@latch.bio](latch.wikimailto:help@latch.bio) or tweet at us [@latchbio](https://twitter.com/LatchBio) and we will get back to you ASAP.
